The kinetic stage of the Euclidean Gas algorithm, as defined by the BAOAB integrator, is a discrete-time approximation of a specific underdamped Langevin stochastic differential equation (SDE). This SDE governs the diffusive part of the generator.

items.label: def-killing-operator
items.title: Interior Killing Operator
items.content:
361: :label: def-killing-operator
362: 
363: Death is modeled by an **interior killing rate** $c: \Omega \to [0, \infty)$, a smooth, non-negative function with the following properties:
364: 
365: 1.  **Safety in the interior**: $c(z) = 0$ for all $z$ in a safe subset of $\Omega$ away from the position boundary.
366: 2.  **Activity near the boundary**: $c(z) > 0$ in a smooth transition layer near $\partial X_{\text{valid}} \times V_{\text{alg}}$.

370:

items.label: def-revival-operator
items.title: Revival Operator
items.content:
379: :label: def-revival-operator
380: 
381: Revival is modeled as a source term that re-injects mass from the dead population back into the alive population. The dead population acts as a reservoir from which revival occurs at a constant rate. The mass killed by the killing operator (see {prf:ref}`def-killing-operator`) flows into this dead reservoir. Dead walkers are instantly revived by cloning from alive companions, so the spatial profile of the re-injected mass is simply **proportional to the current alive density**, mirroring the discrete algorithm's revival mechanism.
382: 
383: The **Revival Operator** is defined as:
384: 
385: $$
386: B[f, m_d](t, z) := \lambda_{\text{revive}} \cdot m_d(t) \cdot \frac{f(t,z)}{m_a(t)}
387: $$
388: 
389: where:
390: *   $\lambda_{\text{revive}} > 0$ is the **revival rate**, a free parameter independent of the timestep (typical values: 0.1-5)
391: *   $m_d(t) = 1 - m_a(t)$ is the current dead mass
392: *   $f(t,z)/m_a(t)$ is the **normalized alive density** (the probability distribution over the alive population)
393: 
394: This form directly translates the discrete algorithm: dead walkers select companions uniformly from the alive set and clone to their positions.
395: 
396: **Key property**: The total mass revived per unit time is:
397: 
398: $$
399: \int_{\Omega} B[f, m_d](t,z)\,\mathrm{d}z = \lambda_{\text{revive}} \cdot m_d(t)
400: $$

items.label: def-cloning-generator
items.title: Internal Cloning Operator (Derived Form)
items.content:
498: :label: def-cloning-generator
499: 
500: The **Internal Cloning Operator**, $S[f]$, is the mean-field limit of the discrete cloning mechanism. It is distinct from the revival operator (see {prf:ref}`def-revival-operator`), which handles dead-to-alive transitions, while this operator redistributes mass within the alive population. It is a mass-neutral, non-local operator that decomposes into sink and source terms:
501: 
502: $$
503: S[f](t, z) = S_{\text{src}}[f](t, z) - S_{\text{sink}}[f](t, z)
504: $$
505: 
506: where:
507: 
508: *   **Sink** (mass removed when walkers at $z$ clone away):
509: 
510:     $$
511:     S_{\text{sink}}[f](t,z) = \frac{1}{\tau} f(t,z) \int_{\Omega} P_{\text{clone}}[f/m_a](z, z_c) \frac{f(t,z_c)}{m_a(t)} \,\mathrm{d}z_c
512:     $$
513: 
514: *   **Source** (mass gained when walkers from other states clone to $z$):
515: 
516:     $$
517:     S_{\text{src}}[f](t,z) = \frac{1}{\tau m_a(t)} \int_{\Omega} \int_{\Omega} f(t,z_d) f(t,z_c) P_{\text{clone}}[f/m_a](z_d, z_c) Q_{\delta}(z \mid z_c) \,\mathrm{d}z_d\,\mathrm{d}z_c
518:     $$
519: 
520: Here:
521: - $P_{\text{clone}}[f/m_a](z_d, z_c)$ is the cloning probability depending on fitness values (see {prf:ref}`def-mean-field-fitness-potential`) computed from the normalized alive density $f/m_a$
522: - $Q_\delta(z \mid z_c)$ is the jitter kernel (Gaussian in position, delta in velocity)
523: - $\tau$ is the discrete timestep, and $1/\tau$ converts per-step probabilities to continuous rates
524: 
525: **Key property**: The operator is mass-neutral by construction. To verify, integrate over $\Omega$:
526: 
527: $$
528: \begin{aligned}
529: \int_{\Omega} S[f](t,z)\,\mathrm{d}z &= \int_{\Omega} S_{\text{src}}[f](t,z)\,\mathrm{d}z - \int_{\Omega} S_{\text{sink}}[f](t,z)\,\mathrm{d}z \\
530: &= \frac{1}{\tau m_a} \int_{\Omega} \int_{\Omega} \int_{\Omega} f(z_d) f(z_c) P(z_d, z_c) Q_\delta(z \mid z_c) \,\mathrm{d}z\,\mathrm{d}z_d\,\mathrm{d}z_c \\
531: &\quad - \frac{1}{\tau} \int_{\Omega} f(z) \int_{\Omega} P(z, z_c) \frac{f(z_c)}{m_a} \,\mathrm{d}z_c\,\mathrm{d}z
532: \end{aligned}
533: $$
534: 
535: Using $\int_\Omega Q_\delta(z \mid z_c)\,\mathrm{d}z = 1$:
536: 
537: $$
538: = \frac{1}{\tau m_a} \int_{\Omega} \int_{\Omega} f(z_d) f(z_c) P(z_d, z_c) \,\mathrm{d}z_d\,\mathrm{d}z_c - \frac{1}{\tau m_a} \int_{\Omega} \int_{\Omega} f(z_d) f(z_c) P(z_d, z_c) \,\mathrm{d}z_d\,\mathrm{d}z_c = 0
539: $$

items.label: def-transport-operator
items.title: Transport Operator and Probability Flux
items.content:
555: :label: def-transport-operator
556: 
557: Let $L$ be the backward kinetic generator from Section 2.2. The **Transport Operator**, denoted $L^\dagger$, is its formal $L^2$-adjoint, which acts on the density $f$. It can be written in conservative form as the negative divergence of a **probability flux vector** $J = (J_x, J_v)$:
558: 
559: $$
560: L^\dagger f = -\nabla \cdot J[f] = -\nabla_x \cdot J_x[f] - \nabla_v \cdot J_v[f]
561: $$
562: 
563: where the components of the flux are:
564: *   **Positional Flux ($J_x$):** $J_x[f] := v f - D_x \nabla_x f$ (Advection + Fickian Diffusion)
565: *   **Velocity Flux ($J_v$):** $J_v[f] := A_v f - D_v \nabla_v f$ (Drift + Fickian Diffusion)
items.raw_directive:
552: The kinetic part of the evolution, described by the generator $\mathcal{L}_{\text{kin}}$ (see {prf:ref}`def-kinetic-generator`), corresponds to a local transport of probability density via drift and diffusion. Its representation in the forward equation is given by the formal adjoint of $\mathcal{L}_{\text{kin}}$, which is the Fokker-Planck operator.
553:

items.section: ## 2. Formal Setup: The Sequence of N-Particle Stationary Measures
items.raw_directive:
125: The analysis in `06_convergence.md` established, via a Foster-Lyapunov drift condition, that for any fixed, finite number of walkers $N \ge 2$, the Euclidean Gas Markov process converges exponentially fast to a unique statistical equilibrium, conditioned on survival. This foundational result provides us with a countably infinite sequence of well-defined N-particle stationary measures. Our strategy is to leverage this sequence to construct the stationary state of the continuous mean-field model. We begin by formally defining these measures.
126: 
127: :::{prf:definition} Sequence of N-Particle QSDs and their Marginals
128: :label: def-sequence-of-qsds
129: 
130: 1.  **The N-Particle Quasi-Stationary Distribution.** For each integer $N \ge 2$, let $\nu_N^{QSD} \in \mathcal{P}(\Sigma_N)$ be the **unique Quasi-Stationary Distribution** for the N-particle Euclidean Gas, whose existence and uniqueness were established in `06_convergence.md`. This is a probability measure on the full N-particle state space $\Sigma_N = (\mathbb{R}^d \times \mathbb{R}^d \times \{0,1\})^N$, describing the long-term statistical behavior of surviving swarm trajectories.
131: 
132: 2.  **The First Marginal Measure.** Let $\mu_N \in \mathcal{P}(\Omega)$ be the **first marginal** of the N-particle measure $\nu_N^{QSD}$. This measure represents the probability distribution of a single, typical particle (e.g., walker $i=1$) when the entire N-particle swarm is in its quasi-stationary equilibrium state. Formally, for any measurable set $A \subseteq \Omega$:
133:     $$
134:     \mu_N(A) := \nu_N^{QSD}(\{ S \in \Sigma_N \mid (x_1, v_1) \in A \})

items.label: def-relative-entropy
items.title: Relative Entropy and Fisher Information
items.content:
237: :label: def-relative-entropy
238: 
239: For probability measures $\mu, \pi$ on a measurable space $(\mathcal{X}, \mathcal{F})$ with $\mu \ll \pi$, the **relative entropy** (KL-divergence) is:
240: 
241: $$
242: D_{\text{KL}}(\mu \| \pi) := \int \frac{d\mu}{d\pi} \log \frac{d\mu}{d\pi} \, d\pi = \int \log \frac{d\mu}{d\pi} \, d\mu
243: $$
244: 
245: The **entropy** of a density $f$ with respect to $\pi$ is:
246: 
247: $$
248: \text{Ent}_\pi(f) := \int f \log f \, d\pi - \left(\int f \, d\pi\right) \log \left(\int f \, d\pi\right)
249: $$
250: 
251: For a probability density $\rho = d\mu/d\pi$, we have $D_{\text{KL}}(\mu \| \pi) = \text{Ent}_\pi(\rho)$.
252: 
253: The **Fisher information** of $\mu$ with respect to a diffusion generator $\mathcal{L}$ is:
254: 
255: $$
256: I(\mu \| \pi) := \int \left|\nabla \log \frac{d\mu}{d\pi}\right|^2 \frac{d\mu}{d\pi} \, d\pi = 4 \int \left|\nabla \sqrt{\frac{d\mu}{d\pi}}\right|^2 d\pi

items.label: def-lsi-continuous
items.title: Logarithmic Sobolev Inequality (LSI)
items.content:
262: :label: def-lsi-continuous
263: 
264: A probability measure $\pi$ on $\mathbb{R}^d$ with generator $\mathcal{L}$ satisfies a **logarithmic Sobolev inequality** with constant $C_{\text{LSI}} > 0$ if for all smooth functions $f > 0$ with $\int f^2 d\pi = 1$:
265: 
266: $$
267: \text{Ent}_\pi(f^2) \le 2C_{\text{LSI}} \cdot \mathcal{E}(f, f)
268: $$
269: 
270: where $\mathcal{E}(f, f) := -\int f \mathcal{L} f \, d\pi$ is the Dirichlet form.
271: 
272: **Equivalent formulation:** For all $f > 0$:
273: 
274: $$
275: \int f^2 \log f^2 \, d\pi - \left(\int f^2 d\pi\right) \log\left(\int f^2 d\pi\right) \le 2C_{\text{LSI}} \int |\nabla f|^2 \, d\pi

items.content:
281: :label: def-discrete-lsi
282: 
283: A Markov kernel $K: \mathcal{X} \to \mathcal{P}(\mathcal{X})$ with invariant measure $\pi$ satisfies a **discrete-time LSI** with constant $C_{\text{LSI}} > 0$ if for all functions $f: \mathcal{X} \to \mathbb{R}_{>0}$:

items.label: def-log-concavity-condition
items.title: Explicit Log-Concavity Condition
items.content:
1050: :label: def-log-concavity-condition
1051: 
1052: For $\rho_{\text{QSD}}(x) \propto \sqrt{\det g(x)} \cdot \exp(-U_{\text{eff}}(x)/T)$ to be log-concave, we require:
1053: 
1054: $$
1055: \nabla^2 \left[\frac{1}{2}\log(\det g(x)) - \frac{U_{\text{eff}}(x)}{T}\right] \preceq 0
1056: $$
1057: 
1058: (Hessian must be negative semi-definite).
1059: 
1060: **Expanding the terms**:
1061: 
1062: $$
1063: \nabla^2 \log(\rho_{\text{QSD}}) = \frac{1}{2}\nabla^2 \log(\det(H(x) + \epsilon_\Sigma I)) - \frac{1}{T}\nabla^2(U(x) - \epsilon_F V_{\text{fit}}(x))
1064: $$
1065: 
1066: where:
1067: - $H(x) = \nabla^2 V_{\text{fit}}(x)$ is the Hessian of the fitness potential
1068: - $V_{\text{fit}}(x)$ itself depends on reward $r(x)$ and swarm density via complex integral

items.label: def-localization-kernel
items.title: Localization Kernel
items.content:
159: :label: def-localization-kernel
160: 
161: For a localization scale $\rho > 0$, the **localization kernel** $K_\rho: \mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{X} \to [0, 1]$ is a smooth, non-negative function satisfying:
162: 
163: 1. **Normalization:** $\int_{\mathcal{X}} K_\rho(x, x') \, dx' = 1$ for all $x \in \mathcal{X}$
164: 
165: 2. **Locality:** $K_\rho(x, x') \to 0$ rapidly as $\|x - x'\| \gg \rho$
166: 
167: 3. **Symmetry:** $K_\rho(x, x') = K_\rho(x', x)$
168: 
169: 4. **Limit Behavior:**
170:    - As $\rho \to 0$: $K_\rho(x, x') \to \delta(x - x')$ (hyper-local)
171:    - As $\rho \to \infty$: $K_\rho(x, x') \to 1/|\mathcal{X}|$ (global)
172: 
173: **Standard Example:** The Gaussian kernel
174: 
175: $$
176: K_\rho(x, x') := \frac{1}{Z_\rho(x)} \exp\left(-\frac{\|x - x'\|^2}{2\rho^2}\right)
177: 
178: $$

items.label: def-localized-mean-field-moments
items.title: Localized Mean-Field Moments
items.content:
195: :label: def-localized-mean-field-moments
196: 
197: For a probability distribution $f \in \mathcal{P}(\mathcal{X} \times \mathbb{R}^d)$, measurement function $d: \mathcal{X} \to \mathbb{R}$, and reference point $x \in \mathcal{X}$, the **ρ-localized statistical moments** are:
198: 
199: **Localized Mean:**
200: 
201: $$
202: \mu_\rho[f, d, x] := \int_{\mathcal{X} \times \mathbb{R}^d} K_\rho(x, x') \, d(x') \, f(x', v) \, dx' \, dv
203: 
204: $$
205: 
206: **Localized Variance:**
207: 
208: $$
209: \sigma^2_\rho[f, d, x] := \int_{\mathcal{X} \times \mathbb{R}^d} K_\rho(x, x') \, [d(x') - \mu_\rho[f, d, x]]^2 \, f(x', v) \, dx' \, dv
210: 
211: $$
212: 
213: **For the N-Particle System:** The full swarm state consists of N walkers, but only the **alive walker set** $A_k \subseteq \{1, \ldots, N\}$ with $|A_k| = k$ participates in the statistical measurements and adaptive dynamics. We define:
214: 
215: **Full Empirical Measure (all walkers, including dead):**
216: 
217: $$
218: f_N := \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^N \delta_{(x_i, v_i)}
219: 
220: $$
221: 
222: This measure describes the complete N-particle state but is **not used** for computing adaptive statistics.
223: 
224: **Alive-Walker Empirical Measure (only alive walkers):**
225: 
226: $$
227: f_k := \frac{1}{k} \sum_{i \in A_k} \delta_{(x_i, v_i)}
228: 
229: $$
230: 
231: This is the measure used for **all** statistical moments, fitness potentials, and adaptive forces. Substituting $f_k$ into the integral definitions above yields the discrete forms:
232: 
233: $$
234: \mu_\rho[f_k, d, x_i] = \sum_{j \in A_k} w_{ij}(\rho) \, d(x_j), \quad w_{ij}(\rho) := \frac{K_\rho(x_i, x_j)}{\sum_{\ell \in A_k} K_\rho(x_i, x_\ell)}
235: 
236: $$
237: 
238: $$
239: \sigma^2_\rho[f_k, d, x_i] = \sum_{j \in A_k} w_{ij}(\rho) \, [d(x_j) - \mu_\rho[f_k, d, x_i]]^2
240: 
241: $$
242: 
243: where $w_{ij}(\rho)$ are the normalized localization weights. The normalization $\sum_{\ell \in A_k} K_\rho(x_i, x_\ell)$ ensures $\sum_{j \in A_k} w_{ij}(\rho) = 1$, making $\mu_\rho$ a convex combination over the alive swarm.

items.label: def-unified-z-score
items.title: Unified Localized Z-Score
items.content:
284: :label: def-unified-z-score
285: 
286: The **unified ρ-dependent Z-score** combines spatial localization with numerical regularization in three steps:
287: 
288: **Step 1: Localized Standard Deviation**
289: 
290: $$
291: \sigma_\rho[f, d, x] := \sqrt{\sigma^2_\rho[f, d, x]}
292: 
293: $$
294: 
295: **Step 2: Numerical Regularization (C¹ Smoothing)**
296: 
297: $$
298: \sigma'_\rho[f, d, x] := \sigma'_{\text{reg}}(\sigma^2_\rho[f, d, x])
299: 
300: $$
301: 
302: where $\sigma'_{\text{reg}}: \mathbb{R}_{\ge 0} \to \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ is the **C^∞ regularized standard deviation function** from `01_fractal_gas_framework.md` (Definition `def-statistical-properties-measurement`). This function is defined as $\sigma'_{\text{reg}}(V) = \sqrt{V + \sigma'^2_{\min}}$, ensuring:
303: - **C^∞ regularity**: $\sigma'_{\text{reg}}$ is infinitely differentiable everywhere
304: - **Positive lower bound**: $\sigma'_{\text{reg}}(V) \ge \sigma'_{\min} > 0$ for all $V \ge 0$
305: - **Global Lipschitz**: $|(\sigma'_{\text{reg}})'(V)| \le L_{\sigma'_{\text{reg}}} = \frac{1}{2\sigma'_{\min}}$ for all $V \ge 0$
306: 
307: **Step 3: Z-Score Construction**
308: 
309: $$
310: Z_\rho[f, d, x] := \frac{d(x) - \mu_\rho[f, d, x]}{\sigma'_\rho[f, d, x]}
311: 
312: $$
313: 
314: **Properties:**
315: - **Boundedness:** If $d$ is bounded, then $Z_\rho$ is uniformly bounded across all $f, x, \rho$.
316: - **Well-posedness:** The regularization ensures $Z_\rho$ is always defined and finite.

items.label: def-hybrid-sde
items.title: The Adaptive Viscous Fluid SDE
items.content:
385: :label: def-hybrid-sde
386: 
387: The evolution of each walker $i \in \{1, \dots, N\}$ is governed by a coupled Stratonovich SDE on the phase space $\mathcal{X} \times \mathbb{R}^d$:
388: 
389: $$
390: \begin{aligned}
391: dx_i &= v_i \, dt \\
392: dv_i &= \left[ \mathbf{F}_{\text{stable}}(x_i) + \mathbf{F}_{\text{adapt}}(x_i, S) + \mathbf{F}_{\text{viscous}}(x_i, S) - \gamma v_i \right] dt + \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) \circ dW_i
393: \end{aligned}
394: 
395: $$
396: 
397: where `S` denotes the full N-particle swarm state. The five components of the dynamics are defined as follows.
398: 
399: **1. The Stability Force (`F_stable`):**
400: The gradient of a static, globally confining potential `U(x)`.
401: 
402: $$
403: \mathbf{F}_{\text{stable}}(x_i) := -\nabla U(x_i)
404: 
405: $$
406: 
407: *   **Role:** The unconditional anchor for stability. It provides a global restoring force that prevents the swarm from drifting to the boundary, guaranteeing recurrence. Its properties are defined by the **Axiom of a Globally Confining Potential** (Axiom 3.1.1).
408: 
409: **2. The Adaptive Force (`F_adapt`):**
410: The gradient of the mean-field fitness potential `V_fit[f_k, ρ]`, scaled by a small parameter `ε_F`.
411: 
412: $$
413: \mathbf{F}_{\text{adapt}}(x_i, S) := \epsilon_F \nabla_{x_i} V_{\text{fit}}[f_k, \rho](x_i)
414: 
415: $$
416: 
417: where $V_{\text{fit}}[f_k, \rho]$ is the fitness potential computed using the **alive-walker empirical measure** $f_k$ and a **finite localization scale ρ > 0** (see Definition {prf:ref}`def-localized-mean-field-fitness`).
418: *   **Role:** Provides intelligent guidance, pushing walkers towards regions of higher fitness as perceived by their **local neighborhood**. The scale ρ controls the spatial extent of this neighborhood. Its properties are defined by the **Axiom of Bounded Adaptive Force** (Axiom 3.2.1).
419: 
420: **3. The Viscous Force (`F_viscous`):**
421: A non-local velocity-coupling term analogous to the viscosity term in the Navier-Stokes equations, scaled by a viscosity parameter `ν`. The coupling uses **row-normalized weights** to ensure N-uniform bounds.
422: 
423: $$
424: \mathbf{F}_{\text{viscous}}(x_i, S) := \nu \sum_{j \neq i} \frac{K(x_i - x_j)}{\sum_{k \neq i} K(x_i - x_k)} (v_j - v_i)
425: 
426: $$
427: 
428: where the normalization factor $\deg(i) := \sum_{k \neq i} K(x_i - x_k)$ is the **local degree** of walker $i$ (total coupling weight to all neighbors).
429: 
430: *   **Role:** Smoothes the velocity field, dissipates relative kinetic energy, and encourages coherent, fluid-like motion. The normalization ensures that the effective coupling strength is bounded independently of $N$, preventing the operator norm from growing with swarm size.
431: *   **Interpretation:** Each neighbor $j$ contributes proportionally to its "visibility weight" $K(x_i - x_j)$ relative to the total visibility $\deg(i)$. This produces a **weighted average** of velocity differences rather than a sum, analogous to SPH (Smoothed Particle Hydrodynamics) normalization.
432: *   **Properties:** Defined by the **Axiom of a Well-Behaved Viscous Kernel** (Axiom 3.2.2).
433: 
434: **4. The Bulk Friction (`-γv_i`):**
435: A standard linear friction term with coefficient `γ > 0`.
436: *   **Role:** Provides unconditional dissipation of kinetic energy, preventing kinetic explosion and ensuring the velocity distribution can thermalize.
437: 
438: **5. The Regularized Adaptive Diffusion (`Σ_reg`):**
439: The matrix square root of the regularized inverse Hessian of the **ρ-localized fitness potential**.
440: 
441: $$
442: \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) := \left( \nabla^2_{x_i} V_{\text{fit}}[f_k, \rho](x_i) + \epsilon_\Sigma I \right)^{-1/2}
443: 
444: $$

382: The central object of study is the following stochastic differential equation, which governs the evolution of each walker in the swarm.
383: 
384: :::{prf:definition} The Adaptive Viscous Fluid SDE

386: 
387: The evolution of each walker $i \in \{1, \dots, N\}$ is governed by a coupled Stratonovich SDE on the phase space $\mathcal{X} \times \mathbb{R}^d$:
388: 
389: $$
390: \begin{aligned}
391: dx_i &= v_i \, dt \\
392: dv_i &= \left[ \mathbf{F}_{\text{stable}}(x_i) + \mathbf{F}_{\text{adapt}}(x_i, S) + \mathbf{F}_{\text{viscous}}(x_i, S) - \gamma v_i \right] dt + \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) \circ dW_i
393: \end{aligned}

431: *   **Interpretation:** Each neighbor $j$ contributes proportionally to its "visibility weight" $K(x_i - x_j)$ relative to the total visibility $\deg(i)$. This produces a **weighted average** of velocity differences rather than a sum, analogous to SPH (Smoothed Particle Hydrodynamics) normalization.

items.title: Regularized Hessian Diffusion Tensor
items.content:
454: :label: def-regularized-hessian-tensor
455: 
456: Let `V_fit(S)` be the N-dimensional fitness potential vector, as defined in `03_cloning.md` (Def. 5.6.1). For each walker `i`, let `V_i(x_1, ..., x_N)` be its fitness potential, viewed as a function of all walker positions. Let `H_i(S) = ∇²_{x_i} V_i` be the Hessian of walker `i`'s fitness with respect to its own position.
457: 
458: The **Regularized Adaptive Diffusion Tensor** for walker `i` is defined as:
459: 
460: $$
461: \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) := \left( H_i(S) + \epsilon_\Sigma I \right)^{-1/2}
462: 
463: $$
464: 
465: where `ε_Σ > 0` is a fixed, small **regularization constant**.
466: 
467: The induced Riemannian metric for the kinetic dynamics is the inverse of the regularized Hessian:
468: 
469: $$
470: G_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) := \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S)^T = \left( H_i(S) + \epsilon_\Sigma I \right)^{-1}

items.label: def-localized-mean-field-fitness
items.title: Localized Mean-Field Fitness Potential
items.content:
495: :label: def-localized-mean-field-fitness
496: 
497: The **ρ-localized mean-field fitness potential** $V_{\text{fit}}[f, \rho]: \mathcal{X} \to \mathbb{R}$ for a walker at position $x \in \mathcal{X}$ is defined as:
498: 
499: $$
500: V_{\text{fit}}[f, \rho](x) := g_A\left( Z_\rho[f, d, x] \right)
501: 
502: $$
503: 
504: where:
505: 
506: 1.  **Rescale Function:** $g_A: \mathbb{R} \to [0, A]$ is a smooth, bounded, monotone increasing function (e.g., $g_A(z) = A/(1 + e^{-z})$).
507: 
508: 2.  **Unified Z-Score:** $Z_\rho[f, d, x]$ is the unified localized Z-score from Definition {prf:ref}`def-unified-z-score`, which combines:
509:    - Localization via kernel $K_\rho(x, x')$
510:    - Statistical moments $\mu_\rho[f, d, x]$ and $\sigma^2_\rho[f, d, x]$ from Definition {prf:ref}`def-localized-mean-field-moments`
511:    - Numerical regularization via $\kappa_{\text{var,min}}$
512: 
513: 3.  **Measurement Function:** $d: \mathcal{X} \to \mathbb{R}$ is a bounded measurement of local objective quality (e.g., reward, distance to target).
514: 
515: **Properties:**
516: - **ρ-Dependence:** The fitness explicitly depends on the localization scale ρ, which controls the spatial extent of statistical aggregation.
517: - **Nonlocality:** For finite ρ, $V_{\text{fit}}[f, \rho](x)$ depends on the distribution $f$ within the ρ-neighborhood of $x$.
518: - **Nonlinearity:** The functional is nonlinear in $f$ due to the Z-score's division by localized standard deviation.
519: - **Boundedness:** $0 \le V_{\text{fit}}[f, \rho](x) \le A$ for all $x, f, \rho$ by construction (due to bounded rescale and regularized Z-score).
520: - **Smoothness:** $V_{\text{fit}}[f, \rho](x)$ is $C^\infty$ in $x$ (provided $f$ is sufficiently regular) due to the smoothness of $g_A$, $K_\rho$, and the regularization.
521: - **Limiting Behavior:**

items.label: def-backbone-sde
items.title: The Backbone SDE
items.content:
1088: :label: def-backbone-sde
1089: 
1090: The **backbone system** is obtained from the full Hybrid SDE ([](#def-hybrid-sde)) by setting all adaptive parameters to zero:
1091: 
1092: $$
1093: \epsilon_F = 0, \quad \nu = 0, \quad \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x, S) = \sigma I
1094: 
1095: $$
1096: 
1097: This yields the simplified SDE:
1098: 
1099: $$
1100: \begin{aligned}
1101: dx_i &= v_i \, dt \\
1102: dv_i &= \left[ -\nabla U(x_i) - \gamma v_i \right] dt + \sigma \, dW_i
1103: \end{aligned}
1104: 
1105: $$
1106: 
1107: The backbone is a **static underdamped Langevin equation** with:
1108: - Globally confining potential $U(x)$
1109: - Constant friction coefficient $\gamma > 0$
1110: - Constant isotropic diffusion $\sigma > 0$

items.label: def-strat-drift
items.title: Stratonovich Drift for the Hybrid System
items.content:
1292: :label: def-strat-drift
1293: 
1294: For the Hybrid SDE with drift:
1295: 
1296: $$
1297: b_i(S) = -\nabla U(x_i) + \epsilon_F \nabla_{x_i} V_{\text{fit}}(S) + \mathbf{F}_{\text{viscous}}(x_i, S) - \gamma v_i
1298: 
1299: $$
1300: 
1301: we define:
1302: 
1303: **Backbone drift:**
1304: 
1305: $$
1306: A_{\text{backbone}}(S) = \sum_{i=1}^N \left[ \langle \nabla_{x_i} V, v_i \rangle + \langle \nabla_{v_i} V, -\nabla U(x_i) - \gamma v_i \rangle \right] + \frac{1}{2} \sigma^2 \sum_{i=1}^N \|\nabla_{v_i} V\|^2
1307: 
1308: $$
1309: 
1310: (This corresponds to $\epsilon_F = 0$, $\nu = 0$, $\Sigma_{\text{reg}} = \sigma I$.)
1311: 
1312: **Adaptive perturbation drift:**
1313: 
1314: $$
1315: A_{\text{perturb}}(S) = \sum_{i=1}^N \langle \nabla_{v_i} V, \epsilon_F \nabla_{x_i} V_{\text{fit}}(S) + \mathbf{F}_{\text{viscous}}(x_i, S) \rangle + A_{\text{diff}}(S)
1316: 
1317: $$
1318: 
1319: where $A_{\text{diff}}(S)$ is the additional drift from the state-dependent diffusion:
1320: 
1321: $$
1322: A_{\text{diff}}(S) = \frac{1}{2} \sum_{i=1}^N \sum_{j=1}^d \left[ (\sigma_{ij}^{\text{reg}} \cdot \nabla_{v_i})(\sigma_{ij}^{\text{reg}} \cdot \nabla_{v_i} V) - \sigma^2 \|\nabla_{v_i} V\|^2 \right]
1323: 
1324: $$
1325: 
1326: The total Stratonovich drift is:
1327: 
1328: $$
1329: A_{\text{full}}(S) = A_{\text{backbone}}(S) + A_{\text{perturb}}(S)
1330:

items.content:
1998: :label: def-entropy-fisher-lsi
1999: 
2000: Let $\mu$ and $\nu$ be probability measures on $(\mathcal{X} \times \mathbb{R}^d)^N$ with $\mu \ll \nu$ (absolutely continuous). Denote the Radon-Nikodym derivative by $h = d\mu/d\nu$.
2001: 
2002: 1. **Relative Entropy (Kullback-Leibler divergence):**
2003: 
2004: $$
2005: \text{Ent}_\nu(\mu) := \int h \log h \, d\nu = \int h \log h \, d\nu
2006: 
2007: $$
2008: 
2009: For a function $f$, we define $\text{Ent}_\nu(f^2) := \text{Ent}_\nu(\mu_f)$ where $d\mu_f = f^2/\int f^2 d\nu \, d\nu$.
2010: 
2011: 2. **Carré du Champ (Fisher Information):**
2012: 
2013: $$
2014: \Gamma_N(f) := \frac{1}{2} \left( \mathcal{L}_N(f^2) - 2f \mathcal{L}_N f \right)
2015:

items.label: def-localization-kernel
items.title: Localization Kernel
items.content:
158: :label: def-localization-kernel
159: 
160: For a localization scale $\rho > 0$, the **localization kernel** $K_\rho: \mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{X} \to [0, 1]$ is a smooth, non-negative function satisfying:
161: 
162: 1. **Normalization:** $\int_{\mathcal{X}} K_\rho(x, x') \, dx' = 1$ for all $x \in \mathcal{X}$
163: 
164: 2. **Locality:** $K_\rho(x, x') \to 0$ rapidly as $\|x - x'\| \gg \rho$
165: 
166: 3. **Symmetry:** $K_\rho(x, x') = K_\rho(x', x)$
167: 
168: 4. **Limit Behavior:**
169:    - As $\rho \to 0$: $K_\rho(x, x') \to \delta(x - x')$ (hyper-local)
170:    - As $\rho \to \infty$: $K_\rho(x, x') \to 1/|\mathcal{X}|$ (global)
171: 
172: **Standard Example:** The Gaussian kernel
173: 
174: $$
175: K_\rho(x, x') := \frac{1}{Z_\rho(x)} \exp\left(-\frac{\|x - x'\|^2}{2\rho^2}\right)
176: $$

items.label: def-localized-mean-field-moments
items.title: Localized Mean-Field Moments
items.content:
193: :label: def-localized-mean-field-moments
194: 
195: For a probability distribution $f \in \mathcal{P}(\mathcal{X} \times \mathbb{R}^d)$, measurement function $d: \mathcal{X} \to \mathbb{R}$, and reference point $x \in \mathcal{X}$, the **ρ-localized statistical moments** are:
196: 
197: **Localized Mean:**
198: 
199: $$
200: \mu_\rho[f, d, x] := \int_{\mathcal{X} \times \mathbb{R}^d} K_\rho(x, x') \, d(x') \, f(x', v) \, dx' \, dv
201: $$
202: 
203: **Localized Variance:**
204: 
205: $$
206: \sigma^2_\rho[f, d, x] := \int_{\mathcal{X} \times \mathbb{R}^d} K_\rho(x, x') \, [d(x') - \mu_\rho[f, d, x]]^2 \, f(x', v) \, dx' \, dv
207: $$
208: 
209: **For the N-Particle System:** The full swarm state consists of N walkers, but only the **alive walker set** $A_k \subseteq \{1, \ldots, N\}$ with $|A_k| = k$ participates in the statistical measurements and adaptive dynamics. We define:
210: 
211: **Full Empirical Measure (all walkers, including dead):**
212: 
213: $$
214: f_N := \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^N \delta_{(x_i, v_i)}
215: $$
216: 
217: This measure describes the complete N-particle state but is **not used** for computing adaptive statistics.
218: 
219: **Alive-Walker Empirical Measure (only alive walkers):**
220: 
221: $$
222: f_k := \frac{1}{k} \sum_{i \in A_k} \delta_{(x_i, v_i)}
223: $$
224: 
225: This is the measure used for **all** statistical moments, fitness potentials, and adaptive forces. Substituting $f_k$ into the integral definitions above yields the discrete forms:
226: 
227: $$
228: \mu_\rho[f_k, d, x_i] = \sum_{j \in A_k} w_{ij}(\rho) \, d(x_j), \quad w_{ij}(\rho) := \frac{K_\rho(x_i, x_j)}{\sum_{\ell \in A_k} K_\rho(x_i, x_\ell)}
229: $$
230: 
231: $$
232: \sigma^2_\rho[f_k, d, x_i] = \sum_{j \in A_k} w_{ij}(\rho) \, [d(x_j) - \mu_\rho[f_k, d, x_i]]^2
233: $$
234: 
235: where $w_{ij}(\rho)$ are the normalized localization weights. The normalization $\sum_{\ell \in A_k} K_\rho(x_i, x_\ell)$ ensures $\sum_{j \in A_k} w_{ij}(\rho) = 1$, making $\mu_\rho$ a convex combination over the alive swarm.

items.label: def-unified-z-score
items.title: Unified Localized Z-Score
items.content:
274: :label: def-unified-z-score
275: 
276: The **unified ρ-dependent Z-score** combines spatial localization with numerical regularization in three steps:
277: 
278: **Step 1: Localized Standard Deviation**
279: 
280: $$
281: \sigma_\rho[f, d, x] := \sqrt{\sigma^2_\rho[f, d, x]}
282: $$
283: 
284: **Step 2: Numerical Regularization (C¹ Smoothing)**
285: 
286: $$
287: \sigma'_\rho[f, d, x] := \sigma'_{\text{reg}}(\sigma^2_\rho[f, d, x])
288: $$
289: 
290: where $\sigma'_{\text{reg}}: \mathbb{R}_{\ge 0} \to \mathbb{R}_{>0}$ is the **C^∞ regularized standard deviation function** from `01_fractal_gas_framework.md` (Definition `def-statistical-properties-measurement`). This function is defined as $\sigma'_{\text{reg}}(V) = \sqrt{V + \sigma'^2_{\min}}$, ensuring:
291: - **C^∞ regularity**: $\sigma'_{\text{reg}}$ is infinitely differentiable everywhere
292: - **Positive lower bound**: $\sigma'_{\text{reg}}(V) \ge \sigma'_{\min} > 0$ for all $V \ge 0$
293: - **Global Lipschitz**: $|(\sigma'_{\text{reg}})'(V)| \le L_{\sigma'_{\text{reg}}} = \frac{1}{2\sigma'_{\min}}$ for all $V \ge 0$
294: 
295: **Step 3: Z-Score Construction**
296: 
297: $$
298: Z_\rho[f, d, x] := \frac{d(x) - \mu_\rho[f, d, x]}{\sigma'_\rho[f, d, x]}
299: $$
300: 
301: **Properties:**
302: - **Boundedness:** If $d$ is bounded, then $Z_\rho$ is uniformly bounded across all $f, x, \rho$.
303: - **Well-posedness:** The regularization ensures $Z_\rho$ is always defined and finite.

items.label: def-hybrid-sde
items.title: The Adaptive Viscous Fluid SDE
items.content:
368: :label: def-hybrid-sde
369: 
370: The evolution of each walker $i \in \{1, \dots, N\}$ is governed by a coupled Stratonovich SDE on the phase space $\mathcal{X} \times \mathbb{R}^d$:
371: 
372: $$
373: \begin{aligned}
374: dx_i &= v_i \, dt \\
375: dv_i &= \left[ \mathbf{F}_{\text{stable}}(x_i) + \mathbf{F}_{\text{adapt}}(x_i, S) + \mathbf{F}_{\text{viscous}}(x_i, S) - \gamma v_i \right] dt + \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) \circ dW_i
376: \end{aligned}
377: $$
378: 
379: where `S` denotes the full N-particle swarm state. The five components of the dynamics are defined as follows.
380: 
381: **1. The Stability Force (`F_stable`):**
382: The gradient of a static, globally confining potential `U(x)`.
383: 
384: $$
385: \mathbf{F}_{\text{stable}}(x_i) := -\nabla U(x_i)
386: $$
387: 
388: *   **Role:** The unconditional anchor for stability. It provides a global restoring force that prevents the swarm from drifting to the boundary, guaranteeing recurrence. Its properties are defined by the **Axiom of a Globally Confining Potential** (Axiom 3.1.1).
389: 
390: **2. The Adaptive Force (`F_adapt`):**
391: The gradient of the mean-field fitness potential `V_fit[f_k, ρ]`, scaled by a small parameter `ε_F`.
392: 
393: $$
394: \mathbf{F}_{\text{adapt}}(x_i, S) := \epsilon_F \nabla_{x_i} V_{\text{fit}}[f_k, \rho](x_i)
395: $$
396: 
397: where $V_{\text{fit}}[f_k, \rho]$ is the fitness potential computed using the **alive-walker empirical measure** $f_k$ and a **finite localization scale ρ > 0** (see Definition {prf:ref}`def-localized-mean-field-fitness`).
398: *   **Role:** Provides intelligent guidance, pushing walkers towards regions of higher fitness as perceived by their **local neighborhood**. The scale ρ controls the spatial extent of this neighborhood. Its properties are defined by the **Axiom of Bounded Adaptive Force** (Axiom 3.2.1).
399: 
400: **3. The Viscous Force (`F_viscous`):**
401: A non-local velocity-coupling term analogous to the viscosity term in the Navier-Stokes equations, scaled by a viscosity parameter `ν`. The coupling uses **row-normalized weights** to ensure N-uniform bounds.
402: 
403: $$
404: \mathbf{F}_{\text{viscous}}(x_i, S) := \nu \sum_{j \neq i} \frac{K(x_i - x_j)}{\sum_{k \neq i} K(x_i - x_k)} (v_j - v_i)
405: $$
406: 
407: where the normalization factor $\deg(i) := \sum_{k \neq i} K(x_i - x_k)$ is the **local degree** of walker $i$ (total coupling weight to all neighbors).
408: 
409: *   **Role:** Smoothes the velocity field, dissipates relative kinetic energy, and encourages coherent, fluid-like motion. The normalization ensures that the effective coupling strength is bounded independently of $N$, preventing the operator norm from growing with swarm size.
410: *   **Interpretation:** Each neighbor $j$ contributes proportionally to its "visibility weight" $K(x_i - x_j)$ relative to the total visibility $\deg(i)$. This produces a **weighted average** of velocity differences rather than a sum, analogous to SPH (Smoothed Particle Hydrodynamics) normalization.
411: *   **Properties:** Defined by the **Axiom of a Well-Behaved Viscous Kernel** (Axiom 3.2.2).
412: 
413: **4. The Bulk Friction (`-γv_i`):**
414: A standard linear friction term with coefficient `γ > 0`.
415: *   **Role:** Provides unconditional dissipation of kinetic energy, preventing kinetic explosion and ensuring the velocity distribution can thermalize.
416: 
417: **5. The Regularized Adaptive Diffusion (`Σ_reg`):**
418: The matrix square root of the regularized inverse Hessian of the **ρ-localized fitness potential**.
419: 
420: $$
421: \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) := \left( \nabla^2_{x_i} V_{\text{fit}}[f_k, \rho](x_i) + \epsilon_\Sigma I \right)^{-1/2}
422: $$

419: 
420: $$
421: \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) := \left( \nabla^2_{x_i} V_{\text{fit}}[f_k, \rho](x_i) + \epsilon_\Sigma I \right)^{-1/2}
422: $$
423:

items.content:
432: :label: def-regularized-hessian-tensor
433: 
434: Let `V_fit(S)` be the N-dimensional fitness potential vector, as defined in `03_cloning.md` (Def. 5.6.1). For each walker `i`, let `V_i(x_1, ..., x_N)` be its fitness potential, viewed as a function of all walker positions. Let `H_i(S) = ∇²_{x_i} V_i` be the Hessian of walker `i`'s fitness with respect to its own position.
435: 
436: The **Regularized Adaptive Diffusion Tensor** for walker `i` is defined as:
437: 
438: $$
439: \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) := \left( H_i(S) + \epsilon_\Sigma I \right)^{-1/2}
440: $$
441: 
442: where `ε_Σ > 0` is a fixed, small **regularization constant**.
443: 
444: The induced Riemannian metric for the kinetic dynamics is the inverse of the regularized Hessian:
445: 
446: $$
447: G_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) := \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S)^T = \left( H_i(S) + \epsilon_\Sigma I \right)^{-1}

items.label: def-localized-mean-field-fitness
items.title: Localized Mean-Field Fitness Potential
items.content:
471: :label: def-localized-mean-field-fitness
472: 
473: The **ρ-localized mean-field fitness potential** $V_{\text{fit}}[f, \rho]: \mathcal{X} \to \mathbb{R}$ for a walker at position $x \in \mathcal{X}$ is defined as:
474: 
475: $$
476: V_{\text{fit}}[f, \rho](x) := g_A\left( Z_\rho[f, d, x] \right)
477: $$
478: 
479: where:
480: 
481: 1.  **Rescale Function:** $g_A: \mathbb{R} \to [0, A]$ is a smooth, bounded, monotone increasing function (e.g., $g_A(z) = A/(1 + e^{-z})$).
482: 
483: 2.  **Unified Z-Score:** $Z_\rho[f, d, x]$ is the unified localized Z-score from Definition {prf:ref}`def-unified-z-score`, which combines:
484:    - Localization via kernel $K_\rho(x, x')$
485:    - Statistical moments $\mu_\rho[f, d, x]$ and $\sigma^2_\rho[f, d, x]$ from Definition {prf:ref}`def-localized-mean-field-moments`
486:    - Numerical regularization via $\kappa_{\text{var,min}}$
487: 
488: 3.  **Measurement Function:** $d: \mathcal{X} \to \mathbb{R}$ is a bounded measurement of local objective quality (e.g., reward, distance to target).
489: 
490: **Properties:**
491: - **ρ-Dependence:** The fitness explicitly depends on the localization scale ρ, which controls the spatial extent of statistical aggregation.
492: - **Nonlocality:** For finite ρ, $V_{\text{fit}}[f, \rho](x)$ depends on the distribution $f$ within the ρ-neighborhood of $x$.
493: - **Nonlinearity:** The functional is nonlinear in $f$ due to the Z-score's division by localized standard deviation.
494: - **Boundedness:** $0 \le V_{\text{fit}}[f, \rho](x) \le A$ for all $x, f, \rho$ by construction (due to bounded rescale and regularized Z-score).
495: - **Smoothness:** $V_{\text{fit}}[f, \rho](x)$ is $C^\infty$ in $x$ (provided $f$ is sufficiently regular) due to the smoothness of $g_A$, $K_\rho$, and the regularization.
496: - **Limiting Behavior:**

items.label: def-backbone-sde
items.title: The Backbone SDE
items.content:
1006: :label: def-backbone-sde
1007: 
1008: The **backbone system** is obtained from the full Hybrid SDE ([](#def-hybrid-sde)) by setting all adaptive parameters to zero:
1009: 
1010: $$
1011: \epsilon_F = 0, \quad \nu = 0, \quad \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x, S) = \sigma I
1012: $$
1013: 
1014: This yields the simplified SDE:
1015: 
1016: $$
1017: \begin{aligned}
1018: dx_i &= v_i \, dt \\
1019: dv_i &= \left[ -\nabla U(x_i) - \gamma v_i \right] dt + \sigma \, dW_i
1020: \end{aligned}
1021: $$
1022: 
1023: The backbone is a **static underdamped Langevin equation** with:
1024: - Globally confining potential $U(x)$
1025: - Constant friction coefficient $\gamma > 0$
1026: - Constant isotropic diffusion $\sigma > 0$

items.label: def-strat-drift
items.title: Stratonovich Drift for the Hybrid System
items.content:
1153: :label: def-strat-drift
1154: 
1155: For the Hybrid SDE with drift:
1156: 
1157: $$
1158: b_i(S) = -\nabla U(x_i) + \epsilon_F \nabla_{x_i} V_{\text{fit}}(S) + \mathbf{F}_{\text{viscous}}(x_i, S) - \gamma v_i
1159: $$
1160: 
1161: we define:
1162: 
1163: **Backbone drift:**
1164: 
1165: $$
1166: A_{\text{backbone}}(S) = \sum_{i=1}^N \left[ \langle \nabla_{x_i} V, v_i \rangle + \langle \nabla_{v_i} V, -\nabla U(x_i) - \gamma v_i \rangle \right] + \frac{1}{2} \sigma^2 \sum_{i=1}^N \|\nabla_{v_i} V\|^2
1167: $$
1168: 
1169: (This corresponds to $\epsilon_F = 0$, $\nu = 0$, $\Sigma_{\text{reg}} = \sigma I$.)
1170: 
1171: **Adaptive perturbation drift:**
1172: 
1173: $$
1174: A_{\text{perturb}}(S) = \sum_{i=1}^N \langle \nabla_{v_i} V, \epsilon_F \nabla_{x_i} V_{\text{fit}}(S) + \mathbf{F}_{\text{viscous}}(x_i, S) \rangle + A_{\text{diff}}(S)
1175: $$
1176: 
1177: where $A_{\text{diff}}(S)$ is the additional drift from the state-dependent diffusion:
1178: 
1179: $$
1180: A_{\text{diff}}(S) = \frac{1}{2} \sum_{i=1}^N \sum_{j=1}^d \left[ (\sigma_{ij}^{\text{reg}} \cdot \nabla_{v_i})(\sigma_{ij}^{\text{reg}} \cdot \nabla_{v_i} V) - \sigma^2 \|\nabla_{v_i} V\|^2 \right]
1181: $$
1182: 
1183: The total Stratonovich drift is:
1184: 
1185: $$
1186: A_{\text{full}}(S) = A_{\text{backbone}}(S) + A_{\text{perturb}}(S)

items.label: def-n-particle-generator-lsi
items.title: The N-Particle Generator for the Adaptive System
items.content:
1745: :label: def-n-particle-generator-lsi
1746: 
1747: The infinitesimal generator $\mathcal{L}_N$ for the N-particle Geometric Viscous Fluid Model acts on sufficiently smooth test functions $f: (\mathcal{X} \times \mathbb{R}^d)^N \to \mathbb{R}$ as:
1748: 
1749: $$
1750: \mathcal{L}_N f = \mathcal{L}_{\text{kin},N} f + \mathcal{L}_{\text{clone},N} f
1751: $$
1752: 
1753: where:
1754: 
1755: **Kinetic Part:**
1756: 
1757: $$
1758: \mathcal{L}_{\text{kin},N} f = \sum_{i=1}^N \left[ v_i \cdot \nabla_{x_i} f + \mathbf{F}_{\text{total}}(x_i, S) \cdot \nabla_{v_i} f + \frac{1}{2} \text{Tr}\left( D_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) \nabla^2_{v_i} f \right) \right]
1759: $$
1760: 
1761: with total force:
1762: 
1763: $$
1764: \mathbf{F}_{\text{total}}(x_i, S) = -\nabla U(x_i) + \epsilon_F \nabla V_{\text{fit}}(S) + \mathbf{F}_{\text{viscous}}(x_i, S) - \gamma v_i
1765: $$
1766: 
1767: and regularized diffusion matrix:
1768: 
1769: $$
1770: D_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) = \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S)^T = (H_i(S) + \epsilon_\Sigma I)^{-1}
1771: $$

items.label: def-entropy-fisher-lsi
items.title: Relative Entropy and Fisher Information
items.content:
1777: :label: def-entropy-fisher-lsi
1778: 
1779: Let $\mu$ and $\nu$ be probability measures on $(\mathcal{X} \times \mathbb{R}^d)^N$ with $\mu \ll \nu$ (absolutely continuous). Denote the Radon-Nikodym derivative by $h = d\mu/d\nu$.
1780: 
1781: 1. **Relative Entropy (Kullback-Leibler divergence):**
1782: 
1783: $$
1784: \text{Ent}_\nu(\mu) := \int h \log h \, d\nu = \int h \log h \, d\nu
1785: $$
1786: 
1787: For a function $f$, we define $\text{Ent}_\nu(f^2) := \text{Ent}_\nu(\mu_f)$ where $d\mu_f = f^2/\int f^2 d\nu \, d\nu$.
1788: 
1789: 2. **Carré du Champ (Fisher Information):**
1790: 
1791: $$
1792: \Gamma_N(f) := \frac{1}{2} \left( \mathcal{L}_N(f^2) - 2f \mathcal{L}_N f \right)
1793: $$
1794: 
1795: For the kinetic part with anisotropic diffusion $D_{\text{reg}}$:
1796: 
1797: $$
1798: \Gamma_N(f) = \frac{1}{2} \sum_{i=1}^N \text{Tr}\left( D_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) \nabla_{v_i} f \otimes \nabla_{v_i} f \right)
1799: $$
1800: 
1801: This can be written more explicitly as:
1802: 
1803: $$
1804: \Gamma_N(f) = \frac{1}{2} \sum_{i=1}^N \left\langle \nabla_{v_i} f, D_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) \nabla_{v_i} f \right\rangle
1805: $$
1806: 
1807: where the diffusion matrix $D_{\text{reg}} = (H_i + \epsilon_\Sigma I)^{-1}$ is symmetric and positive definite by construction.

items.label: def-lsi
items.title: Logarithmic Sobolev Inequality (LSI)
items.content:
1813: :label: def-lsi
1814: 
1815: A probability measure $\nu$ on $(\mathcal{X} \times \mathbb{R}^d)^N$ satisfies a **Logarithmic Sobolev Inequality** with constant $C_{\text{LSI}} > 0$ if for every sufficiently smooth function $f$:
1816: 
1817: $$
1818: \text{Ent}_\nu(f^2) \le C_{\text{LSI}} \int \Gamma_N(f) \, d\nu
1819: $$
1820: 
1821: **Equivalent Formulation (Relative Entropy):** For probability measures $\mu \ll \nu$ with density $h$:
1822: 
1823: $$
1824: \int h \log h \, d\nu \le C_{\text{LSI}} \int \frac{\langle \mathcal{A} h, \mathcal{A} h \rangle}{h} \, d\nu
1825: $$

items.label: def-hk-metric-intro
items.title: Additive Hellinger-Kantorovich Metric for the Fragile Gas
items.content:
37: :label: def-hk-metric-intro
38: 
39: For sub-probability measures $\mu_1, \mu_2$ on $(\mathcal{X}, d)$, we define the **additive Hellinger-Kantorovich distance**:
40: 
41: $$
42: d_{HK}^2(\mu_1, \mu_2) := d_H^2(\mu_1, \mu_2) + W_2^2(\tilde{\mu}_1, \tilde{\mu}_2)
43: 
44: $$
45: 
46: where:
47: - $d_H^2(\mu_1, \mu_2) = \int (\sqrt{f_1} - \sqrt{f_2})^2 d\lambda$ is the Hellinger distance ($f_i = d\mu_i/d\lambda$)
48: - $W_2^2(\tilde{\mu}_1, \tilde{\mu}_2)$ is the Wasserstein-2 distance between normalizations $\tilde{\mu}_i = \mu_i/\|\mu_i\|$
49: 
50: **Relationship to the Canonical HK Metric**: The canonical Hellinger-Kantorovich metric (Liero et al. 2018) uses a cone-geometry construction that couples mass variation and transport through optimal couplings on the extended space. Our additive form is a **simplification** that decouples these components.
51: 
52: **Justification for the Fragile Gas**: This simplified metric is well-suited for the Fragile Gas because:
53: 
54: 1. **Decoupled Dynamics**: The algorithm has **spatially decoupled** mass and transport mechanisms. Mass changes occur through revival (uniform over dead walkers) and cloning (based on fitness, but with Gaussian jitter), while transport happens via Langevin diffusion.
55: 
56: 2. **Modular Analysis**: The additive form enables a **three-lemma decomposition** ({prf:ref}`lem-mass-contraction-revival-death`, {prf:ref}`lem-structural-variance-contraction`, {prf:ref}`lem-kinetic-hellinger-contraction`) where each component is analyzed separately with clear physical interpretation.
57: 
58: 3. **Upper Bound Property**: For measures with comparable mass ($|k_1 - k_2| \ll \sqrt{k_1 k_2}$), the additive form provides an upper bound on the canonical HK distance (Kondratyev, Monsaingeon, Vorotnikov, *Calc. Var.* 2016).

34: The Hellinger-Kantorovich metric is a development in optimal transport theory (Liero, Mielke, Savaré, *Invent. Math.* 2018) that unifies two classical distances: the **Wasserstein metric** (spatial displacement) and the **Hellinger distance** (mass and shape changes).
35: 
36: :::{prf:definition} Additive Hellinger-Kantorovich Metric for the Fragile Gas
37: :label: def-hk-metric-intro
38: 
39: For sub-probability measures $\mu_1, \mu_2$ on $(\mathcal{X}, d)$, we define the **additive Hellinger-Kantorovich distance**:
40: 
41: $$
42: d_{HK}^2(\mu_1, \mu_2) := d_H^2(\mu_1, \mu_2) + W_2^2(\tilde{\mu}_1, \tilde{\mu}_2)
43: 
44: $$
45: 
46: where:
47: - $d_H^2(\mu_1, \mu_2) = \int (\sqrt{f_1} - \sqrt{f_2})^2 d\lambda$ is the Hellinger distance ($f_i = d\mu_i/d\lambda$)
48: - $W_2^2(\tilde{\mu}_1, \tilde{\mu}_2)$ is the Wasserstein-2 distance between normalizations $\tilde{\mu}_i = \mu_i/\|\mu_i\|$
49: 
50: **Relationship to the Canonical HK Metric**: The canonical Hellinger-Kantorovich metric (Liero et al. 2018) uses a cone-geometry construction that couples mass variation and transport through optimal couplings on the extended space. Our additive form is a **simplification** that decouples these components.
51:

53: 
54: 1. **Decoupled Dynamics**: The algorithm has **spatially decoupled** mass and transport mechanisms. Mass changes occur through revival (uniform over dead walkers) and cloning (based on fitness, but with Gaussian jitter), while transport happens via Langevin diffusion.
55: 
56: 2. **Modular Analysis**: The additive form enables a **three-lemma decomposition** ({prf:ref}`lem-mass-contraction-revival-death`, {prf:ref}`lem-structural-variance-contraction`, {prf:ref}`lem-kinetic-hellinger-contraction`) where each component is analyzed separately with clear physical interpretation.

items.title: Swarm Configuration Space
items.content:
87: :label: def-swarm-config-space
88: 
89: The **full swarm configuration space** is:
90: 
91: $$
92: \Sigma_N^{\text{full}} = (\mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{V} \times \{0,1\})^N
93: 
94: $$
95: 
96: where:
97: - $\mathcal{X} \subset \mathbb{R}^d$ is the position state space (Valid Domain)
98: - $\mathcal{V} = \{v \in \mathbb{R}^d : \|v\| \le V_{\text{alg}}\}$ is the velocity ball
99: - $\{0,1\}$ encodes the alive/dead status
100: 
101: The **alive subspace** is:
102: 
103: $$
104: \Sigma_N^{\text{alive}} = \{\mathcal{S} \in \Sigma_N^{\text{full}} : |\mathcal{A}(\mathcal{S})| \ge 1\}
105: 
106: $$

items.label: def-algorithmic-projection-space
items.title: Algorithmic Projection Space
items.content:
112: :label: def-algorithmic-projection-space
113: 
114: The **algorithmic space** $\mathcal{Y} \subset \mathbb{R}^m$ is the range of the projection map $\varphi: \mathcal{X} \times \mathcal{V} \to \mathbb{R}^m$.
115: 
116: For the canonical Geometric Gas with velocity weighting $\lambda_v > 0$:
117: 
118: $$
119: \varphi(x, v) = (x, \lambda_v v) \in \mathbb{R}^d \times \mathbb{R}^d = \mathbb{R}^{2d}
120: 
121: $$
122: 
123: Thus $m = 2d$ and $\mathcal{Y} = \mathcal{X} \times \lambda_v \mathcal{V}$.
124: 
125: The algorithmic metric is the **Sasaki metric**:
126: 
127: $$
128: d_{\mathcal{Y}}^2(\varphi(x_1, v_1), \varphi(x_2, v_2)) = \|x_1 - x_2\|^2 + \lambda_v^2 \|v_1 - v_2\|^2

items.label: def-symmetry-transformation
items.title: Symmetry Transformation
items.content:
136: :label: def-symmetry-transformation
137: 
138: A **symmetry** of a dynamical system $\mathcal{S}_{t+1} \sim \Psi(\mathcal{S}_t, \cdot)$ is a transformation $T: \Sigma_N \to \Sigma_N$ such that:
139: 
140: $$
141: T(\mathcal{S}_{t+1}) \sim \Psi(T(\mathcal{S}_t), \cdot)
142: 
143: $$
144: 
145: in distribution. That is, applying $T$ before or after the dynamics gives statistically equivalent outcomes.
146: 
147: **Types of symmetries:**
148: 1. **Exact symmetry**: The transition kernel is invariant: $\Psi(T(\mathcal{S}), \cdot) = \Psi(\mathcal{S}, \cdot) \circ T^{-1}$
items.raw_directive:
133: ### 2.2. Symmetry Groups: Definitions

136: :label: def-symmetry-transformation
137: 
138: A **symmetry** of a dynamical system $\mathcal{S}_{t+1} \sim \Psi(\mathcal{S}_t, \cdot)$ is a transformation $T: \Sigma_N \to \Sigma_N$ such that:
139: 
140: $$
141: T(\mathcal{S}_{t+1}) \sim \Psi(T(\mathcal{S}_t), \cdot)
142: 
143: $$
144: 
145: in distribution. That is, applying $T$ before or after the dynamics gives statistically equivalent outcomes.
146: 
147: **Types of symmetries:**
148: 1. **Exact symmetry**: The transition kernel is invariant: $\Psi(T(\mathcal{S}), \cdot) = \Psi(\mathcal{S}, \cdot) \circ T^{-1}$
149: 2. **Statistical symmetry**: The quasi-stationary distribution (QSD) is invariant: $T_* \pi_{\text{QSD}} = \pi_{\text{QSD}}$

items.label: def-rho-fitness-potential
items.title: ρ-Localized Fitness Potential
items.content:
193: :label: def-rho-fitness-potential
194: 
195: For localization scale $\rho > 0$, the fitness potential at walker $i$ is:
196: 
197: $$
198: V_{\text{fit}}[f_k, \rho](x_i, v_i) = \eta^{\alpha + \beta} \exp\left(\alpha Z_\rho[f_k, R, (x_i, v_i)] + \beta Z_\rho[f_k, d, (x_i, v_i)]\right)
199: 
200: $$
201: 
202: where:
203: - $f_k = \frac{1}{k}\sum_{j \in A_k} \delta_{(x_j, v_j)}$ is the empirical measure over alive walkers
204: - $Z_\rho[f_k, Q, z]$ is the localized Z-score:
205: 
206: $$
207: Z_\rho[f_k, Q, z] = \frac{Q(z) - \mu_\rho[f_k, Q, z]}{\sigma'_\rho[f_k, Q, z]}
208: 
209: $$

items.title: Emergent Riemannian Metric
items.content:
215: :label: def-emergent-metric
216: 
217: The **emergent metric** is the regularized Hessian of the fitness potential:
218: 
219: $$
220: g(x_i, S) = H_i(S) + \epsilon_\Sigma I
221: 
222: $$
223: 
224: where:
225: 
226: $$
227: H_i(S) = \nabla^2_{x_i} V_{\text{fit}}[f_k, \rho](x_i, v_i)
228: 
229: $$
230: 
231: The **adaptive diffusion tensor** is:
232: 
233: $$
234: D_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) = g(x_i, S)^{-1}
235: 
236: $$

items.label: def-effective-counts-two-scales
items.title: Effective Interaction Counts (Two Scales)
items.content:
176: :label: def-effective-counts-two-scales
177: 
178: **1. Softmax Effective Companions** (scale $\varepsilon_c$):
179: $$
180: k_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)}(i) := \left|\left\{\ell \in \mathcal{A} : d_{\text{alg}}(i,\ell) \leq R_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)}\right\}\right|
181: $$
182: 
183: where:
184: $$
185: R_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)} = \varepsilon_c \sqrt{C_{\text{comp}}^2 + 2\log(k^2)}
186: $$
187: 
188: **Scaling**:
189: $$
190: k_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)}(i) = O(\rho_{\max} \cdot \varepsilon_c^{2d} \cdot (\log k)^d)
191: $$
192: 
193: **Properties**:
194: - Grows logarithmically with $k$
195: - NOT k-uniform
196: - Controls softmax companion sums over $\ell$
197: 
198: **2. Localization Effective Neighbors** (scale $\rho$):
199: $$
200: k_{\text{eff}}^{(\rho)}(i) := \left|\left\{j \in \mathcal{A} : d_{\text{alg}}(i,j) \leq R_{\text{eff}}^{(\rho)}\right\}\right|
201: $$
202: 
203: where:
204: $$
205: R_{\text{eff}}^{(\rho)} = C_\rho \cdot \rho
206: $$
207: 
208: for some constant $C_\rho$ independent of $k$.
209: 
210: **Scaling**:
211: $$
212: k_{\text{eff}}^{(\rho)}(i) = O(\rho_{\max} \cdot \rho^{2d})
213: $$
214: 
215: 
216: **Explicit bound**: The effective neighbor count satisfies:
217: $$
218: k_{\text{eff}}^{(\rho)}(i) \leq C_{\text{vol}} \rho_{\max} \rho^{2d}
219: $$
220: 
221: where $C_{\text{vol}} = \pi^d / \Gamma(d+1)$ is the volume of the unit ball in $\mathbb{R}^{2d}$ (phase space).
222: **Properties**:
223: - Independent of $k$

items.label: def-reg-std-implementation
items.title: Regularized Standard Deviation (Implementation)
items.content:
2395: :::{prf:definition} Regularized Standard Deviation (Implementation)
2396: :label: def-reg-std-implementation
2397: $$
2398: \sigma'_{\text{reg}}(V) = \sqrt{V + \sigma'^2_{\min}}
2399: $$
2400: 
2401: where $\sigma'_{\min} = \sqrt{\kappa_{\text{var,min}} + \varepsilon_{\text{std}}^2}$ with:
2402: - $\kappa_{\text{var,min}} > 0$: Variance floor threshold (typical value: $10^{-8}$ to $10^{-6}$)
2403: - $\varepsilon_{\text{std}} > 0$: Numerical stability parameter (typical value: $10^{-6}$ to $10^{-4}$)
2404: 
2405: **Derivative bounds:**
2406: $$
2407: \begin{align}
2408: L_{\sigma'_{\text{reg}}} &= \frac{1}{2\sigma'_{\min}} \\
2409: L_{\sigma''_{\text{reg}}} &= \frac{1}{4\sigma'^3_{\min}} \\
2410: L_{\sigma'''_{\text{reg}}} &= \frac{3}{8\sigma'^5_{\min}}
2411: \end{align}
2412: $$
2413: 
2414: **Example values** (with $\kappa_{\text{var,min}} = 10^{-6}$, $\varepsilon_{\text{std}} = 10^{-4}$):
2415: - $\sigma'_{\min} \approx 3.16 \times 10^{-4}$
2416: - $L_{\sigma'_{\text{reg}}} \approx 1581.1$
2417: - $L_{\sigma''_{\text{reg}}} \approx 2.50 \times 10^{10}$

items.content:
148: :label: def-effective-counts-two-scales
149: 
150: **1. Softmax Effective Companions** (scale $\varepsilon_c$):
151: 
152: $$
153: k_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)}(i) := \left|\left\{\ell \in \mathcal{A} : d_{\text{alg}}(i,\ell) \leq R_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)}\right\}\right|
154: 
155: $$
156: 
157: where:
158: 
159: $$
160: R_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)} = \varepsilon_c \sqrt{C_{\text{comp}}^2 + 2\log(k^2)}
161: 
162: $$
163: 
164: **Scaling**:
165: 
166: $$
167: k_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)}(i) = O(\rho_{\max} \cdot \varepsilon_c^{2d} \cdot (\log k)^d)
168: 
169: $$
170: 
171: **Properties**:
172: - Grows logarithmically with $k$
173: - NOT k-uniform
174: - Controls softmax companion sums over $\ell$

176: **2. Localization Effective Neighbors** (scale $\rho$):
177: 
178: $$
179: k_{\text{eff}}^{(\rho)}(i) := \left|\left\{j \in \mathcal{A} : d_{\text{alg}}(i,j) \leq R_{\text{eff}}^{(\rho)}\right\}\right|
180: 
181: $$
182: 
183: where:
184: 
185: $$

187: 
188: $$
189: 
190: for some constant $C_\rho$ independent of $k$.
191: 
192: **Scaling**:
193: 
194: $$
195: k_{\text{eff}}^{(\rho)}(i) = O(\rho_{\max} \cdot \rho^{2d})
196: 
197: $$
198: 
199: **Properties**:
200: - Independent of $k$

items.label: def-smooth-phase-space-partition-full
items.title: Smooth Phase-Space Partition
items.content:
1107: :label: def-smooth-phase-space-partition-full
1108: 
1109: Fix a clustering scale $\varepsilon_c > 0$ and cluster centers $\{(y_m, u_m)\}_{m=1}^M$ in phase space.
1110: 
1111: A **smooth partition of unity** is a collection of functions $\{\psi_m : \mathcal{X} \times \mathbb{R}^d \to [0,1]\}_{m=1}^M$ satisfying:
1112: 
1113: 1. **Partition identity**:
1114: 
1115: $$
1116: \sum_{m=1}^M \psi_m(x, v) = 1 \quad \text{for all } (x, v) \in \mathcal{X} \times \mathbb{R}^d
1117: 
1118: $$
1119: 
1120: 2. **Smoothness**: Each $\psi_m \in C^\infty$ with bounded derivatives:
1121: 
1122: $$
1123: \|\nabla^n \psi_m\|_\infty \leq C_{\psi,n} \cdot \varepsilon_c^{-n} \quad \text{for all } n \geq 0
1124: 
1125: $$
1126: 
1127: 3. **Localization**: Each $\psi_m$ has support concentrated near cluster $m$:
1128: 
1129: $$
1130: \psi_m(x, v) = 0 \quad \text{when } d_{\text{alg}}((x,v), (y_m, u_m)) > 2\varepsilon_c
1131: 
1132: $$

items.label: def-diversity-pairing-cinf
items.title: Sequential Stochastic Greedy Pairing (From 03_cloning.md)
items.content:
2363: :label: def-diversity-pairing-cinf
2364: 
2365: From Definition 5.1.2 in `docs/source/1_euclidean_gas/03_cloning.md`:
2366: 
2367: **Inputs**: Alive walkers $\mathcal{A}_t = \{w_1, \ldots, w_k\}$, interaction range $\varepsilon_d > 0$
2368: 
2369: **Operation** (Algorithm 5.1):
2370: 1. Initialize unpaired set $U \leftarrow \mathcal{A}_t$, empty companion map $c$
2371: 2. While $|U| > 1$:
2372:    - Select walker $i$ from $U$, remove from $U$
2373:    - For each $j \in U$, compute weight: $w_{ij} := \exp\left(-\frac{d_{\text{alg}}(i, j)^2}{2\varepsilon_d^2}\right)$
2374:    - Sample companion $c_i$ from softmax distribution: $P(j) = w_{ij} / \sum_{\ell \in U} w_{i\ell}$
2375:    - Remove $c_i$ from $U$
2376:    - Set bidirectional pairing: $c(i) \leftarrow c_i$ and $c(c_i) \leftarrow i$

items.title: Quasi-Stationary Distribution (QSD)
items.content:
326: :label: def-qsd-adaptive
327: 
328: A probability measure $\pi_N$ on $\Sigma_N$ is a **quasi-stationary distribution** for the Geometric Gas if:
329: 
330: 1. **Invariance:** $\mathcal{L}^* \pi_N = 0$ (where $\mathcal{L}^*$ is the adjoint in $L^2(\Sigma_N, \text{vol})$)
331: 2. **Ergodicity:** $\pi_N$ is the unique such invariant measure
items.raw_directive:
323: ### 3.3. The Quasi-Stationary Distribution (QSD)
324: 
325: :::{prf:definition} Quasi-Stationary Distribution (QSD)
326: :label: def-qsd-adaptive
327: 
328: A probability measure $\pi_N$ on $\Sigma_N$ is a **quasi-stationary distribution** for the Geometric Gas if:
329:

items.label: def-lsi-adaptive
items.title: Log-Sobolev Inequality
items.content:
347: :label: def-lsi-adaptive
348: 
349: A probability measure $\mu$ on $\Sigma_N$ satisfies a **Log-Sobolev Inequality** with constant $C_{\text{LSI}} > 0$ if, for all smooth $f: \Sigma_N \to \mathbb{R}_+$ with $\int f^2 d\mu = 1$:
350: 
351: $$
352: \text{Ent}_\mu(f^2) \leq C_{\text{LSI}} \int \Gamma_{\Sigma_{\text{reg}}}(f, f) \, d\mu
353: $$
354: 
355: where:
356: - **Entropy functional:** $\text{Ent}_\mu(f^2) := \int f^2 \log(f^2) d\mu$
items.raw_directive:
344: ### 3.4. Log-Sobolev Inequality (LSI)
345: 
346: :::{prf:definition} Log-Sobolev Inequality
347: :label: def-lsi-adaptive
348: 
349: A probability measure $\mu$ on $\Sigma_N$ satisfies a **Log-Sobolev Inequality** with constant $C_{\text{LSI}} > 0$ if, for all smooth $f: \Sigma_N \to \mathbb{R}_+$ with $\int f^2 d\mu = 1$:
350: 
351: $$
352: \text{Ent}_\mu(f^2) \leq C_{\text{LSI}} \int \Gamma_{\Sigma_{\text{reg}}}(f, f) \, d\mu
353: $$
354: 
355: where:
356: - **Entropy functional:** $\text{Ent}_\mu(f^2) := \int f^2 \log(f^2) d\mu$
357: - **Carré du champ operator:** $\Gamma_{\Sigma_{\text{reg}}}(f, f) := \frac{1}{2} \sum_{i=1}^N \|\Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) \nabla_{v_i} f\|^2$

items.label: def-revival-operator-formal
items.title: Mean-Field Revival Operator (Formal)
items.content:
448: :label: def-revival-operator-formal
449: 
450: The **revival operator** $\mathcal{R}: \mathcal{P}(\Omega) \times [0,1] \to \mathcal{M}^+(\Omega)$ (where $\mathcal{M}^+$ denotes non-negative measures) is defined by:
451: 
452: $$
453: \mathcal{R}[\rho, m_d](x,v) := \lambda_{\text{revive}} \cdot m_d \cdot \frac{\rho(x,v)}{\|\rho\|_{L^1}}
454: 
455: $$
456: 
457: where $\|\rho\|_{L^1} = \int_\Omega \rho(x,v) \, dx dv$ is the total alive mass.
458: 
459: **Properties**:
460: 1. **Mass injection**: $\int_\Omega \mathcal{R}[\rho, m_d] = \lambda_{\text{revive}} m_d$ (transfers mass from dead to alive)
461: 2. **Proportionality**: Revival samples proportionally to current alive density
462: 3. **Normalization**: The factor $1/\|\rho\|_{L^1}$ ensures the distribution shape is preserved

items.label: def-combined-jump-operator
items.title: Combined Jump Operator
items.content:
485: :label: def-combined-jump-operator
486: 
487: Define the **jump operator** $\mathcal{J}: \mathcal{P}(\Omega) \to \mathcal{P}(\Omega)$ that acts over a small time interval $\Delta t$:
488: 
489: $$
490: \mathcal{J}(\rho) := (1 - \int_\Omega \kappa_{\text{kill}} \rho \cdot \Delta t) \cdot \frac{\rho - \kappa_{\text{kill}} \rho \cdot \Delta t}{\text{(normalization)}} + \mathcal{R}[\rho, m_d] \cdot \Delta t
491: 
492: $$
493: 
494: This operator:
495: 1. **Removes mass** via killing: $\rho \mapsto \rho - \kappa_{\text{kill}} \rho \cdot \Delta t$
496: 2. **Adds mass** via revival: Injects $\mathcal{R}[\rho, m_d] \cdot \Delta t$
497: 3. **Conserves total mass**: $\int \mathcal{J}(\rho) = \int \rho$ (in the two-population model)

479: Define the **jump operator** $\mathcal{J}: \mathcal{P}(\Omega) \to \mathcal{P}(\Omega)$ that acts over a small time interval $\Delta t$:
480: 
481: $$
482: \mathcal{J}(\rho) := (1 - \int_\Omega \kappa_{\text{kill}} \rho \cdot \Delta t) \cdot \frac{\rho - \kappa_{\text{kill}} \rho \cdot \Delta t}{\text{(normalization)}} + \mathcal{R}[\rho, m_d] \cdot \Delta t
483: $$
484: 
485: This operator:
486: 1. **Removes mass** via killing: $\rho \mapsto \rho - \kappa_{\text{kill}} \rho \cdot \Delta t$
487: 2. **Adds mass** via revival: Injects $\mathcal{R}[\rho, m_d] \cdot \Delta t$
488: 3. **Conserves total mass**: $\int \mathcal{J}(\rho) = \int \rho$ (in the two-population model)

items.title: Adaptive Diffusion Tensor (from `11_geometric_gas.md`)
items.content:
306: :label: def-d-adaptive-diffusion
307: 
308: For a swarm state $S = \{(x_i, v_i, s_i)\}_{i=1}^N$, the **adaptive diffusion tensor** for walker $i$ is:
309: 
310: $$
311: \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) = \left( H_i(S) + \epsilon_\Sigma I \right)^{-1/2}
312: $$
313: 
314: where:
315: - $H_i(S) = \nabla^2_{x_i} V_{\text{fit}}(S)$ is the Hessian of the fitness potential with respect to walker $i$'s position
316: - $\epsilon_\Sigma > 0$ is the **regularization parameter**
317: - The matrix square root is the unique symmetric positive definite square root
318: 
319: The induced **diffusion matrix** (covariance of the noise) is:
320: 
321: $$
322: D_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) = \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S)^T = \left( H_i(S) + \epsilon_\Sigma I \right)^{-1}

items.label: def-d-kinetic-operator-adaptive
items.title: Kinetic Operator with Adaptive Diffusion
items.content:
519: :label: def-d-kinetic-operator-adaptive
520: 
521: The kinetic operator $\Psi_{\text{kin}}$ evolves the swarm for time $\tau$ according to:
522: 
523: $$
524: \begin{aligned}
525: dx_i &= v_i \, dt \\
526: dv_i &= \left[ F(x_i) - \gamma v_i \right] dt + \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x_i, S) \circ dW_i
527: \end{aligned}
528: $$
529: 
530: where:
531: - $F(x) = -\nabla U(x)$ is the force from the confining potential (Axiom 1.3.1 from `../1_euclidean_gas/06_convergence.md`)
532: - $\gamma > 0$ is the friction coefficient
533: - $W_i$ are independent standard Brownian motions
534: - $\circ$ denotes the **Stratonovich product** (not Itô)
535: 
536: **Why Stratonovich**: The Stratonovich formulation is essential for manifold/geometric settings because:
537: 1. **Chain rule works**: Stratonovich SDEs transform naturally under coordinate changes
538: 2. **Geometric invariance**: The diffusion $(H + \epsilon_\Sigma I)^{-1/2}$ represents intrinsic geometry
539: 3. **No spurious drift**: Itô would add correction terms $\frac{1}{2}\sum_j (D_x\Sigma_{\text{reg}}^{(\cdot,j)})\Sigma_{\text{reg}}^{(\cdot,j)}$ that obscure the physics
540: 
541: **Generator and Discretization Convention**: We present the SDE in Stratonovich form for geometric clarity. However:
542: - **For proofs**: The infinitesimal generator $\mathcal{L}$ uses the **Itô form** with Itô drift:
543: 
544: $$
545: b_{\text{It\hat{o}}}(x,v,S) = [F(x) - \gamma v] + \frac{1}{2}\sum_{j=1}^d (D_x\Sigma_{\text{reg}}^{(\cdot,j)}(x,S))\Sigma_{\text{reg}}^{(\cdot,j)}(x,S)
546: $$
547: 
548:   where $\Sigma_{\text{reg}}^{(\cdot,j)}$ is the $j$-th column and $D_x$ is the Jacobian w.r.t. $x$.
549: 
550: - **For discretization**: To properly simulate this SDE, we use either:
551:   - **Heun's method** (stochastic midpoint) for the Stratonovich form, or
552:   - **Euler-Maruyama** on the Itô form (with the corrected drift above)
553: 
554: Note: Direct application of Euler-Maruyama to the Stratonovich form is inconsistent and should be avoided.

737: :label: def-d-coupled-state

items.label: def-d-coupled-lyapunov
items.title: Coupled Lyapunov Function (from `../1_euclidean_gas/03_cloning.md` and `../1_euclidean_gas/06_convergence.md`)
items.content:
749: :label: def-d-coupled-lyapunov
750: 
751: The **total Lyapunov function** is:
752: 
753: $$
754: V_{\text{total}}(S_1, S_2) = c_V V_{\text{inter}}(S_1, S_2) + c_B V_{\text{boundary}}(S_1, S_2)
755: $$
756: 
757: where $c_V, c_B > 0$ are **coupling constants** to be chosen.
758: 
759: **Inter-Swarm Component:**
760: 
761: $$
762: V_{\text{inter}}(S_1, S_2) = V_W(S_1, S_2) + V_{\text{Var},x}(S_1, S_2) + V_{\text{Var},v}(S_1, S_2)
763: $$
764: 
765: where:
766: 
767: **1. Wasserstein-2 Distance** (with hypocoercive cost):
768: 
769: $$
770: V_W(S_1, S_2) = W_h^2(\mu_1, \mu_2)
771: $$
772: 
773: where $\mu_k$ is the empirical measure of alive walkers in swarm $k$, and $W_h$ is the Wasserstein-2 distance with respect to the **hypocoercive norm** (defined in Section 3.2):
774: 
775: $$
776: \|((\Delta x, \Delta v))\|_h^2 = \|\Delta x\|^2 + \lambda_v \|\Delta v\|^2 + b \langle \Delta x, \Delta v \rangle
777: $$
778: 
779: **2. Position Variance Sum:**
780: 
781: $$
782: V_{\text{Var},x}(S_1, S_2) = V_{\text{Var},x}(S_1) + V_{\text{Var},x}(S_2)
783: $$
784: 
785: where $V_{\text{Var},x}(S_k) = \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i: s_{k,i}=1} \|x_{k,i} - \bar{x}_k\|^2$.
786: 
787: :::{admonition} Normalization by $N$ (not $N_{\text{alive}}$)
788: :class: note

items.title: Hypocoercive Norm (from `../1_euclidean_gas/06_convergence.md`)
items.content:
1223: :label: def-d-hypocoercive-norm
1224: 
1225: For phase-space differences $(\Delta x, \Delta v) \in \mathbb{R}^{2d}$, the **hypocoercive norm squared** is:
1226: 
1227: $$
1228: \|(\Delta x, \Delta v)\|_h^2 = \|\Delta x\|^2 + \lambda_v \|\Delta v\|^2 + b \langle \Delta x, \Delta v \rangle
1229: $$
1230: 
1231: where:
1232: - $\lambda_v > 0$: Velocity weight (typically $\lambda_v \sim 1/\gamma$)
1233: - $b \in \mathbb{R}$: Coupling coefficient (chosen for optimal contraction)
1234: 
1235: **Positive definiteness**: Requires $\lambda_v > b^2/4$.

items.label: def-fitness-algorithmic
items.title: Fitness Potential Construction (Algorithmic Specification)
items.content:
2760: :label: def-fitness-algorithmic
2761: 
2762: For a swarm state $S = \{(x_i, v_i, s_i)\}_{i=1}^N$ with alive walkers $A_k = \{i : s_i = \text{alive}\}$, the fitness potential at position $x \in \mathcal{X}$ is constructed through the following pipeline:
2763: 
2764: **Step 1: Measurement Function.** Given a measurement function $d: \mathcal{X} \to \mathbb{R}$ (e.g., reward, diversity score), evaluate:
2765: 
2766: $$
2767: d_i = d(x_i) \quad \text{for all } i \in A_k
2768: $$
2769: 
2770: **Step 2: Localization Weights.** For localization scale $\rho > 0$ and localization kernel $K_\rho(x, x') = \frac{1}{Z_K(x, \rho)} \exp\left(-\frac{\|x - x'\|^2}{2\rho^2}\right)$, compute normalized weights:
2771: 
2772: $$
2773: w_{ij}(\rho) = \frac{K_\rho(x, x_j)}{\sum_{\ell \in A_k} K_\rho(x, x_\ell)}
2774: $$
2775: 
2776: where the normalization ensures $\sum_{j \in A_k} w_{ij}(\rho) = 1$.
2777: 
2778: **Step 3: Localized Moments.** Compute the ρ-localized mean and variance at position $x$:
2779: 
2780: $$
2781: \mu_\rho[f_k, d, x] = \sum_{j \in A_k} w_{ij}(\rho) \, d_j
2782: $$
2783: 
2784: $$
2785: \sigma^2_\rho[f_k, d, x] = \sum_{j \in A_k} w_{ij}(\rho) \, (d_j - \mu_\rho[f_k, d, x])^2
2786: $$
2787: 
2788: **Step 4: Regularized Standard Deviation.** Apply numerical regularization using a C¹-smooth patching function:
2789: 
2790: $$
2791: \sigma'_\rho[f_k, d, x] = \sigma\'_{\text{reg}}\left(\sqrt{\sigma^2_\rho[f_k, d, x]}\right)
2792: $$
2793: 
2794: where $\sigma\'_{\text{reg}}: [0, \infty) \to [\kappa_{\text{var,min}}, \infty)$ is a C¹-smooth function (see Definition {prf:ref}`def-unified-z-score` in `11_geometric_gas.md`) that:
2795: - Equals $\kappa_{\text{var,min}}$ for $\sigma \le \kappa_{\text{var,min}} - \delta$
2796: - Smoothly transitions through a polynomial patch in $[\kappa_{\text{var,min}} - \delta, \kappa_{\text{var,min}} + \delta]$
2797: - Equals the identity $\sigma$ for $\sigma \ge \kappa_{\text{var,min}} + \delta$
2798: 
2799: This ensures $V_{\text{fit}}$ is C² everywhere, as required for the Hessian to be well-defined.
2800: 
2801: **Step 5: Localized Z-Score.** Compute the standardized measurement:
2802: 
2803: $$
2804: Z_\rho[f_k, d, x] = \frac{d(x) - \mu_\rho[f_k, d, x]}{\sigma'_\rho[f_k, d, x]}
2805: $$
2806: 
2807: **Step 6: Rescale to Bounded Potential.** Apply a smooth, monotone, bounded rescale function $g_A: \mathbb{R} \to [0, A]$ (e.g., $g_A(z) = \frac{A}{1 + e^{-z}}$):
2808: 
2809: $$
2810: V_{\text{fit}}[f_k, \rho](x) = g_A\left(Z_\rho[f_k, d, x]\right)
2811: $$

items.title: Emergent Riemannian Metric (Explicit Construction)
items.content:
3004: :label: def-metric-explicit
3005: 
3006: For a walker at position $x$ in swarm state $S$, the **emergent Riemannian metric** is defined as:
3007: 
3008: $$
3009: g(x, S) = H(x, S) + \epsilon_\Sigma I
3010: $$
3011: 
3012: where:
3013: - $H(x, S) = \nabla^2_x V_{\text{fit}}[f_k, \rho](x)$ is the Hessian from {prf:ref}`thm-explicit-hessian`
3014: - $\epsilon_\Sigma > 0$ is the **regularization parameter**
3015: - $I$ is the $d \times d$ identity matrix
3016: 
3017: The corresponding **diffusion tensor** (inverse of the metric) is:
3018: 
3019: $$
3020: D_{\text{reg}}(x, S) = g(x, S)^{-1} = \left(H(x, S) + \epsilon_\Sigma I\right)^{-1}
3021: $$
3022: 
3023: and the **diffusion coefficient matrix** used in the SDE is:
3024: 
3025: $$
3026: \Sigma_{\text{reg}}(x, S) = D_{\text{reg}}(x, S)^{1/2} = \left(H(x, S) + \epsilon_\Sigma I\right)^{-1/2}

items.label: def-emergent-manifold
items.title: Emergent Riemannian Manifold
items.content:
3237: :label: def-emergent-manifold
3238: 
3239: The metric $g(x, S)$ from {prf:ref}`def-metric-explicit` endows the state space $\mathcal{X}$ with the structure of a **Riemannian manifold** $(\mathcal{X}, g_S)$, where the metric depends parametrically on the swarm state $S$.
3240: 
3241: **Geometric Quantities:**
3242: 
3243: **1. Metric Tensor (Index Form):**
3244: 
3245: $$
3246: g_{ab}(x, S) = \left[\nabla^2_x V_{\text{fit}}[f_k, \rho](x)\right]_{ab} + \epsilon_\Sigma \delta_{ab}
3247: $$
3248: 
3249: **2. Inverse Metric (Contravariant Tensor):**
3250: 
3251: $$
3252: g^{ab}(x, S) = \left[\left(\nabla^2_x V_{\text{fit}}[f_k, \rho](x) + \epsilon_\Sigma I\right)^{-1}\right]_{ab}
3253: $$
3254: 
3255: **3. Volume Element:** The Riemannian volume measure is:
3256: 
3257: $$
3258: d\text{Vol}_g = \sqrt{\det g(x, S)} \, dx
3259: $$
3260: 
3261: **4. Geodesic Equation:** Curves $\gamma(t)$ that minimize length satisfy:
3262: 
3263: $$
3264: \frac{d^2 \gamma^a}{dt^2} + \Gamma^a_{bc}(x, S) \frac{d\gamma^b}{dt} \frac{d\gamma^c}{dt} = 0
3265: $$
3266: 
3267: where $\Gamma^a_{bc}$ are the **Christoffel symbols** computed from $g$ via:
3268: 
3269: $$
3270: \Gamma^a_{bc} = \frac{1}{2} g^{ad} \left(\frac{\partial g_{db}}{\partial x^c} + \frac{\partial g_{dc}}{\partial x^b} - \frac{\partial g_{bc}}{\partial x^d}\right)

206: :label: def-simplified-measurement-cinf
207: 
208: The **simplified measurement function** d: X → ℝ depends only on position. We assume d ∈ C∞(X) with bounded derivatives:
209: 
210: $$
211: \sup_{x \in X} \|\nabla^m d(x)\| \leq C_d^{(m)} < \infty \quad \forall m \geq 0
212: $$
213: 
214: **Examples**: Distance to target set d(x) = dist(x, T) (smoothed), reward landscape d(x) = R(x), entropy proxy d(x) = -log π_ref(x).

items.label: def-localization-kernel-cinf
items.title: Localization Kernel
items.content:
224: :label: def-localization-kernel-cinf
225: 
226: The **Gaussian localization kernel**:
227: 
228: $$
229: K_\rho(r) = \exp\left(-\frac{r^2}{2\rho^2}\right)
230: $$
231: 
232: is real analytic with Hermite polynomial derivatives:
233: 
234: $$
235: \frac{d^m}{dr^m} K_\rho(r) = H_m\left(\frac{r}{\rho}\right) \cdot \rho^{-m} \cdot K_\rho(r)
236: $$
237: 
238: Derivative bounds:
239: 
240: $$
241: \left| \frac{d^m}{dr^m} K_\rho(r) \right| \leq C_{\text{Herm}} \cdot m! \cdot \rho^{-m} \cdot \exp\left(-\frac{r^2}{4\rho^2}\right)
242: $$

items.label: def-pipeline-cinf
items.title: Localized Moments, Regularized Std Dev, Z-Score, Fitness Potential
items.content:
270: :label: def-pipeline-cinf
271: 
272: **Localized mean**:
273: 
274: $$
275: \mu_\rho[f_k, x_i] = \sum_{j \in A_k} w_{ij}(\rho) \cdot d(x_j)
276: $$
277: 
278: **Localized variance**:
279: 
280: $$
281: \sigma^2_\rho[f_k, x_i] = \sum_{j \in A_k} w_{ij}(\rho) \cdot (d(x_j) - \mu_\rho)^2
282: $$
283: 
284: **Regularized standard deviation**: σ'_reg: ℝ_{≥0} → [ε_σ, ∞) satisfying:
285: 1. σ'_reg ∈ C∞ with bounded derivatives: sup_{σ²} |d^m σ'_reg / d(σ²)^m| ≤ C_{σ',m}
286: 2. σ'_reg(σ²) ≥ ε_σ > 0 (prevents division by zero)
287: 3. σ'_reg(σ²) ~ √(σ²) as σ² → ∞
288: 
289: **Z-score**:
290: 
291: $$
292: Z_\rho[f_k, d, x_i] = \frac{d(x_i) - \mu_\rho[f_k, x_i]}{\sigma'_{\text{reg}}(\sigma^2_\rho[f_k, x_i])}
293: $$
294: 
295: **Fitness potential**:
296: 
297: $$
298: V_{\text{fit}}[f_k, \rho](x_i) = g_A(Z_\rho[f_k, d, x_i])
299: $$

items.label: def-gevrey-class-cinf
items.title: Gevrey Classes
items.content:
752: :label: def-gevrey-class-cinf
753: 
754: A function f: U → ℝ (U ⊆ ℝ^d open) belongs to **Gevrey class G^s** (s ≥ 1) if for every compact K ⊆ U, there exist C_K, A_K > 0 such that:
755: 
756: $$
757: \sup_{x \in K} \|\nabla^m f(x)\| \leq C_K \cdot A_K^m \cdot (m!)^s \quad \forall m \geq 0
758: $$
759: 
760: **Special cases**:
761: - s < 1: Real analytic (convergent Taylor series)
762: - s = 1: **Gevrey-1** (borderline, "analytic-Gevrey")

items.label: def-adaptive-generator-cinf
items.title: Adaptive Langevin Generator
items.content:
825: :label: def-adaptive-generator-cinf
826: 
827: The **infinitesimal generator** of the adaptive Langevin dynamics on extended state w = (x, v):
828: 
829: $$
830: \mathcal{L} f(x, v) = v \cdot \nabla_x f + [-\nabla U(x) - \epsilon_F \nabla V_{\text{fit}}(x) - \gamma v] \cdot \nabla_v f + \frac{\gamma}{2\beta} \Delta_v f
831: $$
832: 
833: where:
834: - U(x): confining potential (backbone)
835: - ε_F ∇V_fit(x): adaptive force
836: - γ: friction
837: - Δ_v: velocity Laplacian (thermal noise)

items.label: def-effective-counts-two-scales
items.title: Effective Interaction Counts (Two Scales)
items.content:
194: :label: def-effective-counts-two-scales
195: 
196: **1. Softmax Effective Companions** (scale $\varepsilon_c$):
197: 
198: $$
199: k_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)}(i) := \left|\left\{\ell \in \mathcal{A} : d_{\text{alg}}(i,\ell) \leq R_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)}\right\}\right|
200: $$
201: 
202: where:
203: 
204: $$
205: R_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)} = \varepsilon_c \sqrt{C_{\text{comp}}^2 + 2\log(k^2)}
206: $$
207: 
208: **Scaling**:
209: 
210: $$
211: k_{\text{eff}}^{(\varepsilon_c)}(i) = O(\rho_{\max} \cdot \varepsilon_c^{2d} \cdot (\log k)^d)
212: $$
213: 
214: **Properties**:
215: - Grows logarithmically with $k$
216: - NOT k-uniform
217: - Controls softmax companion sums over $\ell$
218: 
219: **2. Localization Effective Neighbors** (scale $\rho$):
220: 
221: $$
222: k_{\text{eff}}^{(\rho)}(i) := \left|\left\{j \in \mathcal{A} : d_{\text{alg}}(i,j) \leq R_{\text{eff}}^{(\rho)}\right\}\right|
223: $$
224: 
225: where:
226: 
227: $$
228: R_{\text{eff}}^{(\rho)} = C_\rho \cdot \rho
229: $$
230: 
231: for some constant $C_\rho$ independent of $k$.
232: 
233: **Scaling**:
234: 
235: $$
236: k_{\text{eff}}^{(\rho)}(i) = O(\rho_{\max} \cdot \rho^{2d})
237: $$
238: 
239: **Properties**:
240: - Independent of $k$

items.label: def-smooth-phase-space-partition-full
items.title: Smooth Phase-Space Partition
items.content:
1131: :label: def-smooth-phase-space-partition-full
1132: 
1133: Fix a clustering scale $\varepsilon_c > 0$ and cluster centers $\{(y_m, u_m)\}_{m=1}^M$ in phase space.
1134: 
1135: A **smooth partition of unity** is a collection of functions $\{\psi_m : \mathcal{X} \times \mathbb{R}^d \to [0,1]\}_{m=1}^M$ satisfying:
1136: 
1137: 1. **Partition identity**:
1138: 
1139: $$
1140: \sum_{m=1}^M \psi_m(x, v) = 1 \quad \text{for all } (x, v) \in \mathcal{X} \times \mathbb{R}^d
1141: 
1142: $$
1143: 
1144: 2. **Smoothness**: Each $\psi_m \in C^\infty$ with bounded derivatives:
1145: 
1146: $$
1147: \|\nabla^n \psi_m\|_\infty \leq C_{\psi,n} \cdot \varepsilon_c^{-n} \quad \text{for all } n \geq 0
1148: 
1149: $$
1150: 
1151: 3. **Localization**: Each $\psi_m$ has support concentrated near cluster $m$:
1152: 
1153: $$
1154: \psi_m(x, v) = 0 \quad \text{when } d_{\text{alg}}((x,v), (y_m, u_m)) > 2\varepsilon_c
1155: 
1156: $$

1279: - $\sum_{m=1}^M \alpha_{j,m} = 1$ (walker belongs to all clusters with fractional weights)
1280: - $\alpha_{j,m} \geq 1/2$ if $d_{\text{alg}}(j, m) \leq \varepsilon_c/2$ (strong membership near center)

items.label: def-diversity-pairing-cinf
items.title: Sequential Stochastic Greedy Pairing (From 03_cloning.md)
items.content:
2186: :label: def-diversity-pairing-cinf
2187: 
2188: From Definition 5.1.2 in `docs/source/1_euclidean_gas/03_cloning.md`:
2189: 
2190: **Inputs**: Alive walkers $\mathcal{A}_t = \{w_1, \ldots, w_k\}$, interaction range $\varepsilon_d > 0$
2191: 
2192: **Operation** (Algorithm 5.1):
2193: 1. Initialize unpaired set $U \leftarrow \mathcal{A}_t$, empty companion map $c$
2194: 2. While $|U| > 1$:
2195:    - Select walker $i$ from $U$, remove from $U$
2196:    - For each $j \in U$, compute weight: $w_{ij} := \exp\left(-\frac{d_{\text{alg}}(i, j)^2}{2\varepsilon_d^2}\right)$
2197:    - Sample companion $c_i$ from softmax distribution: $P(j) = w_{ij} / \sum_{\ell \in U} w_{i\ell}$
2198:    - Remove $c_i$ from $U$
2199:    - Set bidirectional pairing: $c(i) \leftarrow c_i$ and $c(c_i) \leftarrow i$

2209: The idealized model assigns probability to each perfect matching $M \in \mathcal{M}_k$ via:

2221: $$
